docs.title: For Linux Users
docs.text: Linux is really easy there is guide by what distro you have 1. Arch Linux based: sudo pacman -S python3 2. Debian based (Ubuntu applies too): sudo apt install python3 3. RHEL based: sudo yum install python3 or sudo dnf install python3 4. Fedora based: sudo dnf install python3 5. Gentoo based: sudo emerge dev-lang/python and done you already have pyth0n

docs.title: Setting up IDE (Integrated Development Environment)
docs.text: You can use any IDE or code editor For choosing there it is

docs.title: Choosing the IDE or Code Editor
docs.text: I mostly prefer Visual Studio Codium for easy development and fast setup You can use PyCharm Community Edition as most proffessional developers use it but the con of this it works kinda slow on mid-low end computers/laptops and downloading the installor is mostly big You might say why not Visual Studio Code?

docs.title: VSCode vs VSCodium
docs.text: Visual Studio is Open-Source-Software but the binaries are not builded from Open-Source Code While Visual Studio Codium is a manual builded version with patches for telemetry being disabled but also there is no some of extensions from VSCode as it uses Open VSX

docs.title: VSCodium
docs.text:
For Arch-based distros:

sudo pacman -S vscodium

For Other distros please download it from VSCodium WebSite After downloading appropriate file then install it with these commands For Debian-based distros:

sudo apt install <file.deb>

For RHEL-based distros:

sudo yum install <file.rpm>
or
sudo dnf install <file.rpm>

For Fedora-based distros:

sudo dnf install <file.rpm>

For Gentoo-based distros: Sorry, dig it out for yourself as you are pro

docs.title: VSCode
docs.text:
For Arch-based distros:

sudo pacman -S code

For Debian-based distros:

sudo apt install code

For RHEL-based distros:

sudo yum install code
or
sudo dnf install code

For Fedora-based distros:

sudo dnf install code

For Gentoo-based distros: Sorry, dig it out for yourself as you are pro

docs.title: Pycharm CE
docs.text:
For Arch-based distro

sudo pacman -S pycharm-community-edition

For Other distros please download it from Pycharm Community Edition, or please read the manual to add the repo and install it Gentoo users: If your machine can handle it then c'mon
